Link Mash (May 8, 2014)

May 8, 2014
1 minute read

The weekly Link Mash is a curated selection of tools, stories, and other links that I found during my travels on the web. All of my curated links can be found on  my Pinboard; you can also find the Link Mash archives here.

  • Why Atom Can’t Replace Vim. With news of GitHub’s Atom editor going open source, this article has reignited my interest in learning vim.
  • The many faces of Bill Murray: An illustrated compilation. I’ve loved Bill Murray since childhood (where Ghostbusters was my favorite movie). This is such a neat depiction of his career.
  • Mingle: Action-Based Contacts Could Be The Best, Fastest Contacts App. Great iOS app for managing “contact actions”, even via customized URL schemes. Can’t wait to see where this goes.
  • HoverReader. Because I’m not attention-span-challenged enough: “Get an instant preview and read an entire article without leaving the page you are on! All you have to do is hover over any link!”
  • Remote pbcopy on OS X systems. While on the subject of pbcopy, why not allow for it to be used over SSH?
  • JoshCheek/pbcopy. If you use a Mac and use a terminal, you’ve no doubt come across pbcopy (and if not, you should learn to love it). This awesome little gem allows for the same thing inside Ruby; imagine being in an IRB/PRY session and dynamically copying data!
  • “Pavlovian password management” aims to change sloppy habits. I love this concept. If I pick a password that will take modern technology a trillion years to crack, I shouldn’t have to change it every 90 days. Are you listening, MS Exchange?
  • ltk/kurtz-kloud. One developer’s quest to find the perfect screenshot app led to the greatest reason to be a developer (I think): “I couldn’t find what I was looking for, so I built Kloud.”
  • Project Naptha. You’re telling me I can copy/paste text in images in Chrome??
  • Ruby · Styleguide. A great reference for writing clean, clear Ruby.

This Link Mash was generated by PinPress, a simple tool to generate text templates from Pinboard data.
